questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a history of intravenous heroin use.  He takes no medications.  His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptomatic relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. This patient has no signs of radiculopathy, and he has only had symptoms for 2 days, so epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent for back strain, strict bed rest is not recommended because this may actually lead to deconditioning and worse pain. Studies have shown that bed rest is associated with a longer recovery time compared to mild to moderate activity in patients with acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

C) CORRECT:

Analgesia, preferably with NSAIDs, and continuation of normal activities (except strenuous exercise) is the treatment of choice for acute musculoskeletal lower back pain. Almost all cases of musculoskeletal lower back pain resolve on their own within ∼ 6 weeks. Analgesia reduces discomfort, and mild to moderate activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest. Further testing (e.g., MRI) should be considered in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion for a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Muscle relaxants such as cyclobenzaprine or tizanidine can be used as alternatives or in combination with NSAIDs for the treatment of acute lower back pain.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the spine may be indicated in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion of a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Although a history of IV drug use is a red flag for infection (e.g., epidural abscess), this patient has none of the typical features (e.g., fever, rigors, specific tender point, neurological deficits). This patient's recent history and physical examination strongly suggest acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures manifest with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fracture (e.g., > 50 years old, osteoporosis, or malignancy) or after significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on exam. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, did not experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.

F) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients if a bacterial cause of lower back pain is suspected (eg, epidural abscess, osteomyelitis). This patient is at increased risk of infection (history of IV drug use); however, he has no history of fever. Furthermore, patients with lower back pain caused by infection are typically more severely ill.
questions.hint: This patient has acute back pain  without features of radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g., shooting or shock-like pain, weakness, numbness) following a task that likely involved lifting heavy objects, which is consistent with acute lower back strain.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of urinary and fecal incontinence for 6 hours. Earlier in the day, he fell off a ladder at a construction site and sustained injuries to his back and thighs but did not seek medical attention. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Examination shows tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ in the ankles and 2+ in the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound shows a distended bladder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The cerebellum is supplied by the posterior circulation, and a stroke in this region can be due to dissection of the vertebral artery as a result of trauma. However, cerebellar stroke usually manifests with unilateral signs of ataxia, which this patient lacks. In addition, a cerebellar stroke would not explain this patient's bilateral motor weakness, hyperreflexia of the ankles, and bowel and bladder dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

F) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing back pain for the past 2 weeks. She is unable to perform her daily chores. One month ago, she fell and hurt her back while working outside in the garden. The pain subsided with over-the-counter acetaminophen. She underwent a left mastectomy 1 year ago for breast cancer. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and a multivitamin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows thoracic vertebral tenderness. She has mild stiffness on neck flexion. Muscle strength is decreased in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to pain, fine touch, temperature, and proprioception is intact. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, and leukocyte count is 19,300/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) without further diagnostic workup is recommended for the treatment of benign musculoskeletal causes of back pain, such as muscle strain and mild to moderate spinal stenosis or spinal disk herniation. While bed rest can be considered in patients with severe unspecific back pain, early mobilization is indicated in most patients with back pain due to muscular or ligamentous strain. However, patients with signs of infection (e.g., fever and leukocytosis) and focal neurological findings require an urgent diagnostic workup.

B) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the spine can be helpful in the diagnostic workup of various causes of back pain, such as vertebral fractures, spinal stenosis, degenerative spondylolisthesis, and metastases to the bony spine. However, x-ray is not the first-line imaging study in patients with suspected spinal infection because of its low specificity and sensitivity, especially in the first few weeks of infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with methylprednisone) is used to treat patients with suspected malignant compression of the spine. This patient has a history of breast cancer, and vertebral bodies are a common location of breast cancer metastasis. However, this patient's features strongly suggest spinal infection, which may be exacerbated by corticosteroid therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antimicrobial therapy for spinal infections is indicated in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess, new or progressive neurological symptoms, and/or signs of hemodynamic instability or sepsis. Vancomycin is part of the recommended empiric antibiotic therapy for spinal infections. Although vancomycin has excellent coverage of gram-positive pathogens including methicillin-resistant S. aureus, it does not cover gram-negative pathogens and is therefore usually administered in combination with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin. Nafcillin also covers only gram-positive pathogens and would not increase the coverage of vancomycin.

E) CORRECT:

MRI of the spine is the first-line imaging modality for patients with suspected spinal infections. MRI provides high-resolution imaging, which helps to determine the location and extent of the infection and facilitates the planning of surgical intervention. Two sets of blood cultures should also be obtained to identify the causative pathogen. Empiric antimicrobial therapy for spinal infections is indicated in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess, new or progressive neurological symptoms, and/or signs of hemodynamic instability or sepsis; if none of these features are present, antibiotic therapy can be delayed until the causative organism is identified. Additionally, given this patient's neurological deficits, surgical drainage and decompression should also be considered.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

High signal intensity collections are seen in the posterior epidural space. The largest collection (blue overlay) causes anterior displacement and high-grade compression of the spinal cord from C7-T2. The appearance is consistent with epidural abscess. The differential would also include epidural hematoma.

High signal intensity consistent with osteomyelitis and discitis involves the C6 and C7 vertebral bodies (green overlay), prevertebral soft tissues (red overlay), and intervening disc space (yellow overlay).
questions.hint: Back pain, fever, leukocytosis, and focal neurological findings (lower extremity weakness) in a patient with diabetes and a history of trauma to the back raise concern for spinal infection (e.g., spinal epidural abscess, vertebral osteomyelitis).

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. During the last several days, she has had trouble urinating. Three years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and was treated with lumpectomy and radiation. Her only medication is anastrozole. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Neurologic examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 2/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Knee and ankle reflexes are 1+ on the right. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

B) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain that radiates to lower limbs is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's history of breast cancer, spinal imaging including MRI is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.
questions.hint: Two features specific to this patient's diagnosis are severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness.

questions.text: One day after undergoing a right hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 55-year-old woman is evaluated for a 5-hour history of progressively worsening back pain and difficulty moving her legs. Her initial postoperative course was uncomplicated. Current medications include prophylactic subcutaneous heparin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a well-positioned epidural catheter site without redness or swelling. There is weakness of the lower extremities and decreased anal tone. Deep tendon reflexes are absent in both legs. Sensation to pinprick is decreased from below the umbilicus. Her hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6000/m3, and platelet count is 215,000/mm3. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 19 mm/h. A T2-weighted MRI of the spine is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic spinal epidural hematomas typically resolve spontaneously and can therefore be managed conservatively. This patient presents with signs of acute spinal cord compression, for which another step in management is more appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Spinal epidural hematomas can occur as a complication of neuraxial anesthesia, especially in patients with additional risk factors for bleeding (e.g., those taking anticoagulation therapy). If suspected, an MRI should be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If signs of spinal cord compression are present, treatment consists of immediate neurosurgical decompression of the spinal canal via laminectomy, followed by evacuation of the hematoma. During the procedure, the dura should be inspected and active bleeding sites (usually the venous vessels) should be controlled. Any coagulopathies should be treated (e.g., with anticoagulation reversal).

C) INCORRECT:

Early initiation of empiric antibiotic therapy with vancomycin and cefepime is indicated for a spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which can manifest with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural lesion on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA also typically have fever, leukocytosis, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration and specimen collection for culture should be conducted in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which manifests with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural collection on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA typically have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, fever, and local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are obtained prior to initiating treatment in patients with suspected spinal epidural abscess (SEA), which can manifest with back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense epidural lesion on T2-weighted MRI. Unlike this patient, individuals with SEA also typically have fever, leukocytosis, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and/or local point tenderness. Moreover, symptoms of SEA secondary to epidural catheter insertion usually occur ≥ 5 days after the procedure.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute back pain, signs of spinal cord compression, and a hyperintense, epidural space-occupying lesion at the level of the T11-L1 vertebrae, which are consistent with a spinal epidural hematoma, most likely due to epidural catheter insertion.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of low back pain and weakness for the past 4 weeks. He says that the pain is sharp, radiates to his left side, and has a burning quality. He has had a cough occasionally productive of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 months. He has had 3.2-kg (7.0-lb) weight loss in that time. He is now unable to walk without assistance and has had constipation and difficulty urinating for the past 2 weeks. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Neurologic examination shows 3/5 strength of the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are hyperreflexive. Babinski sign is present bilaterally. Sensory examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick below the T4 dermatome. He is unable to lie recumbent due to severe pain. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple round opacities of varying sizes in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression of the spinal cord and resection of the tumor (if operable), is the definitive treatment option in the management of neoplastic spinal cord compression. While it is certainly indicated to improve long-term outcomes, it is not the best first step in management.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical stabilization of the spine in patients with metastatic bone disease can prevent further neurologic or skeletal damage from occurring (e.g., compression fracture). While it could improve long-term outcomes (e.g., maintaining the ability to walk), it would not be the first step in management.

C) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is a treatment option for patients with spinal metastases. It can help control local tumor growth and reduce pain. However, because this patient presents with symptoms of cord compression, it is not the first step in management.

D) CORRECT:

Although an MRI should be conducted ASAP, this patient is currently unable to lie recumbent for the procedure. Emergent high-dose intravenous corticosteroid therapy (e.g., with dexamethasone) is indicated for patients with neurologic deficits from spinal cord compression due to malignancy. Glucocorticoids reduce pain, inflammation, and edema, preventing further neurologic damage until definitive treatment is available (e.g., urgent decompression surgery). Patients with spinal cord compression often have such severe pain that thorough neurologic exam and imaging (particularly with MRI) becomes challenging and the use of glucocorticoids and analgesics can be helpful for this situation.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous acyclovir is the treatment for complicated or disseminated varicella-zoster virus infection, which may manifest with sharp or burning pain and rarely, neurologic deficits (direct infection of cerebral arteries that may cause ischemia or intracerebral hemorrhage). This patient's duration and progression of symptoms, along with the absence of vesicular rash, make this etiology unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone and azithromycin is a commonly used empiric treatment regimen for patients with community-acquired pneumonia, which may manifest with productive cough and lung opacities on chest x-ray. However, pneumonia would not explain this patient's neurologic symptoms.

G) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen, are common analgesic agents for the treatment of back pain and degenerative disk disease. Although NSAIDs can be used as adjunctive therapy to help control pain in this situation, they are not the best first step for this patient presenting with symptoms of cord compression.
questions.hint: This 76-year-old patient with extensive smoking history presents with hemoptysis, weight loss, back pain, and imaging concerning for pulmonary metastases. His back pain and neurologic symptoms are suggestive of compressive myelopathy due to metastases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of intermittent lower back pain for 1 week. His symptoms began shortly after lifting heavy boxes at work. He has not had any fever, chills, or weight loss. He has a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild paraspinal lumbar tenderness. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. An x-ray of the spine shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that may be used for mild musculoskeletal pain. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease because they reduce the production of gastroprotective prostaglandins, increasing the risk of complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.

B) CORRECT:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are indicated as first-line agents in the treatment of acute, uncomplicated back pain for the short-term relief of symptoms. If monotherapy with NSAIDs does not provide adequate pain relief or is contraindicated (e.g., peptic ulcer disease, renal dysfunction), nonbenzodiazepine muscle relaxants (e.g., cyclobenzaprine, tizanidine, metaxalone) can be used as an adjunctive or alternative treatment option. Acetaminophen has limited efficacy for treating acute lower back pain but can also be considered in patients with contraindications to NSAIDs. Selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g., celecoxib) are another treatment option for patients who require gastric protection. In addition to pharmacological management, early mobilization, superficial application of heat, spinal manipulation, and massage are also recommended. Most cases of acute back pain self-resolve within 4–6 weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Opioids (e.g., oxycodone, tramadol) are not indicated as first-line therapy for patients with only mild musculoskeletal back pain. Instead, they are used in the treatment of severe or refractory back pain (e.g., tumor pain).

D) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that may be used for mild musculoskeletal pain. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease because they reduce the production of gastroprotective prostaglandins, increasing the risk of complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
questions.hint: Conservative management with analgesics and physical therapy is recommended for acute, mild musculoskeletal back pain, but some medications can exacerbate preexisting comorbidities and pharmacotherapy should therefore be chosen carefully.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Neurologic examination shows reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; the right side is normal. The resting anal sphincter tone is normal but the squeeze tone is reduced. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. He has not seen any blood in his urine. His only daily medication is ibuprofen, which does not provide adequate pain relief. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Subacute lower back pain worsened by palpation is a typical manifestation of a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). However, SEA is commonly associated with further symptoms, such as fever, malaise, and, eventually, neurologic deficits (secondary to spinal cord compression). Moreover, this patient has no risk factors for this condition (e.g., IV drug use, recent invasive spinal procedures, immunosuppression). While SEA can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Lack of improvement after 6 weeks of therapy with NSAIDs should further raise suspicion for a nonmuscular cause of the pain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe low back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant throughout the day and night and radiates to the posterior aspect of the thighs, stopping at the knees. He describes the pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. He has a past medical history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes insulin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 128/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows:

No vertebral point tenderness
No costovertebral angle tenderness
Grossly intact sensation in the lower extremities
5/5 muscle strength in the lower extremities
+2 deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities
Negative straight leg test
Posterior L4 tender point on the right transverse process

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Counterstrain to the lumbar tender point

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with acute musculoskeletal low back pain, conservative management, e.g., osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT), may be considered alone or alongside pharmacological treatment (preferably NSAIDs). OMT options for back strain range from counterstrain (used to treat tender points) to muscle energy or high velocity, low amplitude techniques (used to target restrictions). Patients should be advised that nonstrenuous activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest and that most acute back pain resolves without treatment in 4 to 6 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the spine is the first-line imaging modality for patients with new or rapidly progressive neurological findings (e.g., spinal epidural abscess, spinal epidural hematoma, vertebral osteomyelitis) or whose symptoms have not resolved within 4 to 6 weeks of therapy. While diabetes is a risk factor for spinal epidural abscess, this patient has no fever or neurological deficits, and history and physical examination findings are highly suggestive of a musculoskeletal cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent in back strain, strict bed rest is contraindicated because it may lead to deconditioning and worsen pain. Studies have shown that in acute musculoskeletal low back pain, bed rest is associated with a longer recovery time than usual activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptom relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. As this patient has no signs of radiculopathy and his back pain began 2 days ago, epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures also present with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fractures (e.g., age > 50 years, osteoporosis, or malignancy) after a significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on examination. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, didn't experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.
questions.hint: This patient has acute back pain with no signs of spinal cord compression (neurological findings are normal), radiculopathy (negative straight leg test), infection or malignancy (no fever, pain that worsens at night, or point tenderness), or referred pain from a nonspinal etiology (no costovertebral angle tenderness). The onset of pain followed a task that likely involved heavy lifting, which is consistent with an acute musculoskeletal low back strain.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents to the office with a 1-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in the lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. He also has had a loss of sensitivity around his buttocks and inner thighs as well as increased trouble urinating the last week. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with prostate cancer and was treated with radiation therapy. Physical examination reveals:

Reduced deep tendon reflexes and muscle strength in the left lower extremity
Normal findings in the right lower extremity
Anal sphincter tone is reduced

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging including MRI is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents to the office with a 3-week history of gradually worsening sharp, stabbing pain in her lower back. The pain radiates to the back of her right leg and is worse at night. She reports decreased sensation around her buttocks and inner thighs. She has also had trouble urinating for several days. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg.
Physical examination reveals:


4/5 muscle strength in the left lower extremity

2/5 muscle strength in the right lower extremity

+1/4 knee and ankle reflexes in the right lower extremity
Anal sphincter tone is reduced

A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan reveals a T-score of -3.0 SD. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome (CMS) is caused by damage to the spinal cord segments T12–L2 and can manifest with lower back pain, radicular pain, distal paresis, perianal numbness, and urinary incontinence. The onset of symptoms is typically sudden, whereas this patient's symptoms have developed gradually over 3 weeks. In addition, distal paresis in patients with CMS is usually symmetric, in contrast to this patient's asymmetric weakness. Finally, CMS is not associated with decreased sensation of the thighs.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome can result in weakness and urinary retention. However, the weakness associated with central cord syndrome is usually symmetric and more prominent in the upper extremities. In addition, patients with this condition often experience loss of pain and temperature sensation in dermatomes near the level of the spinal cord lesion. Finally, central cord syndrome does not typically cause radiculopathy or decreased perianal and thigh sensation.

C) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetric lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in the knee and ankle, saddle anesthesia, bladder dysfunction, decreased anal tone, and severe back pain radiating to the lower limbs is characteristic of cauda equina syndrome. Cauda equina syndrome is typically caused by traumatic injury, disc herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given this patient's dual-energy x-ray scan results, she likely has postmenopausal osteoporosis and should undergo spinal imaging to assess for vertebral fractures.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome classically results in symmetric loss of motor function and pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion. This patient has asymmetric symptoms, including unilateral radicular pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome can result in unilateral lower extremity weakness and urinary retention. This condition is characteristically associated with ipsilateral diminished sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the spinal lesion, whereas this patient has unilateral radicular pain.
questions.hint: Severe radicular pain and asymmetric weakness are characteristic of this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with lung cancer that has metastasized to the ribs and spine presents to clinic with uncontrolled back pain that leaves her unable to sit for long periods. She also has mild burning pain in her hands and feet that is attributed to chemotherapy-induced neuropathy. She has received palliative radiation to part of her spine.
On examination, she is in severe distress. She has been taking tramadol 50 mg by mouth every 8 hours and acetaminophen, with minimal pain relief.
In addition to starting dexamethasone empirically and obtaining an MRI of the spine to rule out cord compression, what is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Add pregabalin and titrate as tolerated
Initiate treatment with buprenorphine around the clock and adequate rescue doses
Refer for admission, and initiate treatment with bolus doses of intravenous morphine sulfate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticonvulsants, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are sometimes used to treat neuropathic pain but take time to titrate to an adequate dose. Furthermore, they have no proven role in the treatment of pain associated with osseous metastases, which is the first priority in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Partial agonists, such as buprenorphine, have little if any use in the treatment of acute cancer pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients who have not responded to moderate doses of tramadol should be switched to opioid-based therapy rather than have their tramadol dose titrated. Tramadol is a weak opioid, and strong opioids are the preferred agents for moderate-to-severe cancer pain, according to the World Health Organization stepladder for cancer pain in adults.

D) CORRECT:

Escalating severe back pain in the setting of known spine metastases should immediately trigger concern for impending cord compression, even in the absence of neurologic deficits. If assessment for cord compression is delayed until neurologic deficits occur, it may be too late to prevent permanent neurologic injury. An MRI should be ordered immediately for this patient and dexamethasone should be administered empirically until cord compression is ruled out. In addition, her pain should be promptly addressed.

Single-agent pure opioid agonists, such as morphine and hydromorphone, are the preferred treatments for acute cancer pain like this patient is experiencing. In an opioid-naive patient, 2 mg to 5 mg of intravenous morphine (or an equianalgesic dose of another parenteral opioid) is a reasonable initial dose. In a patient who is opioid tolerant, it is reasonable to administer an intravenous opioid dose equivalent to 10% to 20% of the amount of opioid used in the past 24 hours. Doses can be escalated by 50% to 100% every 15 to 30 minutes as tolerated until analgesia is achieved. Once titration results in good pain control, the patient can be switched to a maintenance regimen with intermittent rescue dosing or patient-controlled analgesia with or without a basal rate.

Key learning point: In addition to starting dexamethasone empirically and obtaining an MRI of the spine to rule out cord compression, the most appropriate approach to managing intractable back pain in a patient with metastatic cancer is to initiate bolus doses of intravenous opioids.

E) INCORRECT:

Fentanyl patches take several hours to have an effect and should therefore not be used to start therapy when fast pain relief is desired.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman with a history of tobacco use, hypertension, and hypothyroidism presents with low back pain that developed last night while she was lifting boxes in her apartment. At that time, she felt a sharp pop in the back followed by acute onset of severe lumbar back pain. Over the next few hours, the pain began to radiate down both legs into her feet and became fairly severe. She took ibuprofen last night, but the pain has not improved. She requests hydrocodone because it helped with postsurgical shoulder pain last year. She has had no fever or incontinence, and she has no history of cancer.
Her physical examination is significant for absence of sensation in the perineum, bilateral mild foot drop, and reduced rectal tone. She is able to walk but seems to be in a lot of pain.
An emergency MRI of the lumbar spine shows a large posterior disk herniation at L5–S1 with complete effacement of the cauda equina.
In addition to hospitalization for monitoring, what is the most appropriate step next in management for this patient?

choices.text: Opioid analgesia and referral for elective spine surgery
Referral for emergency decompressive spine surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids could be considered while awaiting surgery, but the surgery should be done immediately, not electively.

B) CORRECT:

This patient demonstrates multiple features consistent with cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is a surgical emergency due to compression of the nerve roots that form the cauda equina, causing back pain and radicular pain, motor and sensory deficits (which can be bilateral or unilateral), and dysfunction of the urinary and anal sphincters. It is commonly caused by disk herniation, as in this case, or by malignancy. Untreated CES can result in irreversible neurologic deficits; if it is suspected, the most appropriate diagnostic modality is an emergency MRI of the spine. If CES is confirmed, the most appropriate treatment is immediate surgical decompression.

Key learning point: In patients with acute neurologic deficits of cauda equina syndrome (severe low back pain with neurologic deficits), the appropriate treatment is emergency decompressive spine surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections are not indicated as initial treatments in cauda equina syndrome, because these interventions would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Vertebroplasty is not indicated as initial treatment in cauda equina syndrome, because this intervention would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Intensive physical therapy is not indicated as initial treatment in cauda equina syndrome, because it would not address the risk of permanent neurologic deficits.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man who is an offensive lineman on his college football team reports a 2-month history of low back pain that began approximately 3 weeks after starting football practice. He has been able to play with the pain, but it has been getting worse. He initially felt the pain only after practice and games but now feels it all the time, except when sleeping.
The pain is left-sided more than right-sided and does not radiate into the legs. The patient reports no back pain before this recent episode, nor any morning joint stiffness. The pain has not improved despite self-treatment with rest and stretching.
Active and passive movement of the lumbar spine is painful, and the pain is exacerbated by extension and hyperextension testing, although range of motion is normal. Straight-leg-raise testing is negative bilaterally. Neurologic examination of the lower extremities is normal.
Which one of the following abnormalities is most likely to be seen on radiographs (including oblique views) of this patient's lumbosacral spine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disk injury is typically characterized by pain radiating to the lower extremities and by numbness and tingling, none of which are present in this patient. Features of disk herniation are not readily visible on a radiograph.

B) CORRECT:

Spondylolysis of the lumbar spine is a frequent cause of low back pain in young athletes. Spondylolysis refers to a stress fracture in the pars interarticularis of the lumbar spine, a component of the posterior elements of the vertebra. The condition most commonly involves the L5 vertebra, often in athletes who participate in sports that involve repetitive lumbar extension or twisting, such as gymnastics and soccer, or in athletes who play specific sports positions, such as linemen in football.

The back pain almost always develops insidiously and worsens gradually, as in other overuse injuries. Physical examination usually reveals pain that is exacerbated by extension on one or both sides, typically worsening with hyperextension. Further evaluation of patients with suspected spondylolysis can include plain-film radiography, bone imaging with single-photon emission CT, or MRI.

Key learning point: An athlete with low back pain that is exacerbated by extension should be evaluated for spondylolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Sacroiliitis is generally associated with morning stiffness and is not typically associated with painful movement of the lumbar spine. One of the most typical causes of sacroiliitis in young adults is ankylosing spondylitis, an inflammatory disorder, more common in men than women, that typically begins in early adulthood and can affect the spine as well as the hips and ribs, leading to fusion of the spinal vertebrae.

D) INCORRECT:

A vertebral body fracture is often the result of trauma or bone fragility (e.g., osteoporosis or malignancy). It manifests with pain in the area of the fracture (thoracic and lumbar being most common). Given this patient’s age and lack of an overt history of trauma, fracture would be unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Schmorl nodes are thought to be a herniation of the lumbar disc into the vertebral body. They can be seen on MRI or plain films. They are more commonly seen in older patients with degenerative spine disease but can be seen in younger patients as well.

F) INCORRECT:

Facet stress fractures are uncommon, and they typically manifest with pain on lateral flexion

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with low back pain for 3 weeks and bilateral leg weakness and fevers for the past 3 to 4 days. Initially, he attributed his symptoms to a flulike illness, but as of this morning, he is unable to walk because of weakness, and the pain is radiating down his legs.
In addition to lower-extremity weakness and back pain, his examination is notable for a temperature of 39.0°C, an extensor response on plantar reflex testing, hyperreflexia of the lower extremities, and reduced anal sphincter tone.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Obtain a plain-film series of the spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute and subacute presentations of spinal cord compression should raise concern for a malignant etiology. Sarcoma, lymphoma, neuroblastoma, and in rare instances, leukemia have all been reported to cause spinal cord compression in children. An infectious process, such as a spinal epidural abscess, may also manifest with fever, back pain, and weakness. However, definitive imaging, such as MRI, should be performed before initiation of antibiotics. Imaging may reveal a rim-enhancing lesion, and a cerebrospinal fluid sample for culture would ideally be obtained before treatment initiation.

B) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture, used to diagnose meningitis or encephalitis, is not indicated in this patient, as he does not have signs or symptoms consistent with a meningeal process.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms suggestive of acute spinal cord compression, including lower-extremity weakness and pain, reduced anal sphincter tone, and an upgoing plantar reflex. His fever and rapid onset of symptoms are suggestive of an acute process that should be treated as a medical emergency. Although prompt treatment is imperative to the preservation or return of function, urgent imaging is necessary to guide the appropriate diagnostic workup and therapy.

MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for spinal cord compression. It is useful to assess soft tissues, ligaments, disks, and the spinal cord. It can identify the presence of an epidural mass compressing the spinal cord as well as metastatic disease within the cord, which may be missed on CT. High T2-signal abnormalities above and below the site of compression can indicate the presence of edema, suggesting an acute compression.

Key learning point: Patients who present with lower-extremity weakness, back and leg pain, and upgoing toes on plantar reflex testing should undergo MRI to rule out spinal cord compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Management for a patient presenting with signs of spinal cord compression may include intravenous dexamethasone to reduce edema before definitive management with surgical decompression, chemotherapy, or in some cancers, radiation therapy. Because imaging may not distinguish an infectious process (such as a spinal epidermal abscess) from a lymphoma or sarcoma, consultation with neurosurgery, oncology, and infectious disease is recommended before initiating glucocorticoids. Imaging would precede administration of glucocorticoids, however. If an infectious process is unlikely and awaiting subspecialty consultation will significantly delay management (such as may be the case in a smaller or rural hospital), intravenous glucocorticoids should be considered with the goal of preserving function.

E) INCORRECT:

Although plain films are the least expensive imaging modality and are easy to obtain, they have significant limitations for detecting spinal cord compression. They can be useful for evaluating osseous structures and alignment of vertebrae, but they cannot assess the spinal cord and are no longer considered a first-line imaging tool when spinal cord compression is suspected.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
