questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the office because of severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant and nonradiating, and he describes it as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain began after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows old track marks on the cubital fossae bilaterally. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Flexing the hip and extending the knee while raising the leg to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is not impaired. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptomatic relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. This patient has no signs of radiculopathy, and he has only had symptoms for 2 days, so epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent for back strain, strict bed rest is not recommended because this may actually lead to deconditioning and worse pain. Studies have shown that bed rest is associated with a lengthier recovery time compared to mild to moderate activity in patients with acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

C) CORRECT:

Analgesia, preferably with NSAIDs, and continuation of normal activities (except strenuous exercise) is the treatment of choice for acute musculoskeletal lower back pain. Almost all cases of musculoskeletal lower back pain resolve on their own within ∼ 6 weeks. Analgesia reduces discomfort, and mild to moderate activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest. Further testing (e.g., MRI) should be considered in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion for a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. Muscle relaxants such as cyclobenzaprine or tizanidine can be used as alternatives or in combination with NSAIDs for the treatment of acute lower back pain.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI of the spine may be indicated in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion of a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. This patient has none of the typical features (e.g., fever, rigors, specific tender point, neurological deficits) of an infection, and his recent history and physical examination strongly suggest acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures also present with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fracture (e.g., > 50 years old, osteoporosis, or malignancy) or after significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on exam. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, did not experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.
questions.hint: This patient has acute back pain without features of radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g., shooting or shock-like pain, weakness, numbness) following a task that likely involved lifting heavy objects, which is consistent with acute lower back strain.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of worsening lower back pain for 6 weeks. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and that it sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has noticed a weakened urinary stream. Examination shows no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

B) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a 10-year history of chronic midline low back pain, with episodes that have gradually worsened over the past year. The pain worsens when sitting and is present on most days. He reports no leg weakness, numbness, bowel or bladder dysfunction, or saddle anesthesia. The pain is not aggravated by walking. Acetaminophen, NSAIDs, and physical therapy have not provided lasting relief. A recent MRI revealed moderate spinal stenosis at the L4 level and 5-mm spondylolisthesis at the L5–S1 level. On examination, there is no lumbar tenderness. Lower extremity reflexes, muscle strength, and sensation to pinprick and light touch are normal. Pulses are 2+ in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Spinal fusion for multilevel degenerative disc disease

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has low back pain associated with degenerative disc disease, mild spondylolisthesis, and moderate spinal stenosis in the lower lumbar area. These abnormalities are not uncommon in both symptomatic and asymptomatic middle-aged and older people, and they are not themselves indications for surgery.

A structured multimodal and multidisciplinary noninvasive pain management is the most appropriate next step. There is no single intervention that guarantees dramatic improvement, but studies have shown various combinations of physical therapy, exercise programs, cognitive behavioral or mindfulness-based therapies, and nonopioid analgesics to be beneficial for many patients. Because complete resolution of chronic back pain is unlikely in this case, it is important to establish realistic goals and expectations.

See “Red flags for back pain” table.

Key learning point: Chronic low back pain without focal neurologic findings is usually not an indication for surgery and is best managed with a noninvasive multimodal approach that may include a supervised exercise program, psychological interventions, and pharmacologic treatments.

B) INCORRECT:

Discectomy is usually reserved for patients with symptoms from nerve root compression, which is also not present in this case. Clinical trials have not clearly shown spinal fusion to be superior to noninvasive treatment in patients who have nonspecific low back pain associated with multilevel degenerative disc disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Clinical trials have not clearly shown spinal fusion to be superior to noninvasive treatment in patients who have nonspecific low back pain associated with multilevel degenerative disc disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Decompressive laminectomy should generally be reserved for patients with neurogenic claudication, progressive neurologic deficits in the lower extremities, or both. However, neither finding is present in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Implantable spinal cord stimulators are not indicated for generally functional patients who have nonspecific low back pain.
questions.hint: There are no red flags for back pain based on this patient's history and focused neurological examination.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department reporting difficulty walking. She awoke this morning with lower back pain, which she has had before, but then throughout the day, she had difficulty lifting her legs, which she has never experienced before. She also had an episode of urinary incontinence. She denies any problems with speech or vision and has not noticed any weakness in her arms. She is typically active and walks several miles every morning. She reports no recent injuries. Vital signs are within normal limits. Her mental status and cranial nerves are intact. She has strong upper extremities with normal sensation and reflexes. In her lower extremities, she has 4/5 strength with hip flexion. Sensation is diminished in both inner thighs. Legs have normal tone, but her rectal tone is diminished. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for this patient?

choices.text: Plain-film radiograph of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not indicated in this case, as there is no reason to suspect infection or hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

Although CT can demonstrate a herniated disk and plain-film radiographs are helpful for identifying fractures, neither modality is adequately sensitive for identifying spinal-cord or nerve-root damage, infections, or tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Although CT can demonstrate a herniated disk and plain-film radiographs are helpful for identifying fractures, neither modality is adequately sensitive for identifying spinal-cord or nerve-root damage, infections, or tumors.

D) CORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is usually related to lumbar disc pathology but can also be the result of spinal stenosis, tumor, infection, or injury. It should be treated as a neurologic emergency to prevent permanent symptoms. It classically manifests with back pain, leg weakness, bowel or bladder sphincter dysfunction, and sensory abnormalities involving the inner thigh.

Patients with suspected CES should undergo urgent MRI of the lumbar spine, followed by consultation with a neurosurgeon if compression is present. MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for evaluating the spinal cord and nerve roots.

Key learning point: In a patient with acute-onset back pain, lower-extremity weakness, sensory changes, urinary incontinence, and loss of rectal tone, the most appropriate initial diagnostic test is urgent MRI of the lumbar spine, followed by neurosurgical consultation for possible cauda equina syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

A nerve-conduction study is not typically helpful in the acute setting because it may not show abnormalities early on in the disease course.
questions.hint: This patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings localize to the cauda equina.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with metastatic lung cancer presents with a week of progressive mid-thoracic back pain that disrupts his sleep. He now requires help walking due to mild bilateral leg weakness. Neurologic evaluation shows 3/5 strength from the hips downward and decreased pinprick sensation to the mid-thigh bilaterally. Temperature is 36.8°C, and vital signs are stable.

Temperature
36.8°C

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: High-dose intravenous corticosteroids and urgent MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression requires precise localization of the lesion, which imaging provides. MRI confirms the diagnosis, identifies the lesion's location, and excludes other causes like abscess or hemorrhage. Imaging ensures that surgical intervention is accurately targeted and safe.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with metastatic lung cancer presenting with new back pain and neurologic deficits, malignant epidural spinal cord compression is a concern. High-dose intravenous corticosteroids, such as dexamethasone, reduce edema and prevent further spinal cord injury. An urgent MRI is crucial for localizing the lesion, assessing compression extent, and guiding definitive management, such as radiotherapy or surgical decompression. This approach prevents irreversible neurologic deficits by combining immediate medical stabilization with prompt diagnostic imaging.

Key learning point: In cancer patients with new onset back pain, high-dose IV corticosteroids should be administered immediately to prevent neurological deterioration, and an MRI should be performed to assess for spinal cord compression.

C) INCORRECT:

While urgent MRI is essential for diagnosing spinal cord compression, it should not delay the immediate administration of high-dose corticosteroids. Corticosteroids reduce inflammatory edema and prevent further neurological deterioration, which is critical in the presence of progressive neurologic deficits.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioids provide pain relief but do not address the underlying spinal cord compression causing neurological deficits. High doses risk sedation, obscuring neurological assessments and delaying urgent diagnostic evaluations. The priority is identifying and managing the compressive lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to your clinic with a 2-month history of low back pain. He has no red flags. He insists on obtaining a lumbar MRI because he fears a spinal cord compression. Previous plain radiographs were normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer him to an orthopedic surgeon.
Prescribe a short course of opioids.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referring patients without neurological impairment or persistent symptoms after appropriate treatment exposes them to unnecessary specialist evaluations and delays effective initial care.

B) INCORRECT:

Opioids should not be used as first-line therapy for nonspecific low back pain due to the risks of dependence, overdose, and minimal long-term benefit. When analgesics are required, nonselective NSAIDs are the preferred option.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeated plain radiographs are not indicated in patients with low back pain without new symptoms or red flags, as they expose patients to unnecessary radiation and divert resources from more effective treatments.

D) INCORRECT:

Although a patient’s fear of spinal cord compression might seem to warrant an MRI, the absence of red flags and a normal plain radiograph suggests a low likelihood of serious pathology. Early advanced imaging (e.g., MRI) often reveals incidental findings, which can lead to unnecessary interventions and inefficient use of healthcare resources.

E) CORRECT:

Conservative management is indicated for patients with nonspecific low back pain. Evidence-based guidelines show that ordering early advanced imaging (e.g., MRI) does not improve patient outcomes but increases the risk of incidental findings and unnecessary outcomes. According to the Canadian Medical Association Code of Ethics, physicians must act in the best interests of patients while using healthcare resources fairly and wisely. Physiotherapy helps to reduce pain and improve function through structured exercise programs, patient education, and self-management support.

Key learning point: Physicians should use healthcare resources responsibly by adhering to evidence-based guidelines, prioritizing interventions with proven benefits, and avoiding unnecessary tests or referrals.
questions.hint: This patient’s subacute low back pain, normal imaging, and absence of red flags are consistent with nonspecific back pain.

questions.text: You are seeing a 47-year-old man in the emergency department who presents with urinary and fecal incontinence for the past 6 hours. Earlier today, he fell off a ladder at a construction site, injuring his back and thighs, but did not seek medical attention at that time. He took ibuprofen for lower back pain. His temperature is 36.9°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. On examination, there is tenderness over the lumbar spine and bilateral symmetric lower extremity weakness. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ at the ankles and 2+ at the knees. Rectal tone is decreased. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a distended bladder. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) can be due to compression of the nerve roots below where the spinal cord terminates, which may be caused by trauma. However, CES typically manifests with asymmetric muscle weakness, decreased reflexes, and saddle anesthesia due to damage of the lower motor neurons, which is not consistent with this patient's symmetric muscle weakness and hyperreflexia. In addition, bowel and bladder dysfunction are late findings of CES and would not be expected within hours of injury. Lastly, because of nerve root compression, the pain usually radiates along the sensory distribution of the nerves affected.

B) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause cord compression, resulting in symptoms of weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and back pain, which are seen in this patient. However, spinal epidural abscess results in systemic symptoms, such as fever and malaise, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the absence of common risk factors for epidural abscess (e.g., IV drug use, recent spine procedure, and contiguous soft tissue infection) and the recent trauma suggest another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome can manifest with acute motor weakness and bowel and bladder dysfunction as a result of occlusion of the anterior spinal cord artery and ischemia to the corticospinal tracts and autonomic fibers. However, in this syndrome, the spinothalamic tract is also affected, resulting in pain and temperature sensation deficits, which this patient lacks.

D) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome manifests with ipsilateral proprioception and vibration sense loss, ipsilateral flaccid paralysis, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature, which are not consistent with the neurological findings in this patient. Instead, this patient has bilateral lower extremity weakness without sensory deficits. Furthermore, a fall is unlikely to result in Brown-Sequard syndrome, which is usually caused by penetrating injuries to the back.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has conus medullaris syndrome as a result of compression of the most distal region of the spinal cord from his recent accident. Conus medullaris syndrome typically manifests with both upper and lower motor neuron signs. Bladder and bowel dysfunction within hours of the injury, hyperreflexia of the ankles, symmetric lower extremity weakness, and back pain are all consistent with this diagnosis (see “Compressive myelopathies” table).

Key learning point: Conus medullaris syndrome presents with sudden bladder and bowel dysfunction, symmetric lower limb weakness, and mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs due to injury at the distal spinal cord.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.
questions.hint: The patient's history of recent trauma and current symptoms are consistent with spinal compression.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of sharp, stabbing pain in his lower back that radiates to the back of his left leg. Over the past week, he has also noticed decreased sensation around his buttocks and inner thighs, along with increased difficulty urinating. He was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago and received radiation therapy. Neurologic examination reveals reduced strength and reflexes in the left lower extremity; findings on the right are normal. Resting anal sphincter tone is normal, but squeeze tone is reduced. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome may cause the similar symptoms as seen in this patient, although they usually occur symmetrically with a sudden onset. This patient's symptoms developed over the course of 2 weeks and are asymmetric. Additionally, the knee-jerk reflexes are often spared and numbness is primarily limited to the perianal region, since conus medullaris syndrome typically involves sacral spinal cord segments, and not L3 and L4 (which control the knee-jerk reflex and innervate the saddle region beyond the perianal area). Radiating radicular pain also tends to be less severe in patients with conus medullaris syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Brown-Sequard syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would present with unilateral lower limb weakness, as seen here. However, the affected side would also present with loss of vibration and proprioception and the contralateral side would show loss of pain and temperature sensation, features which are absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

The gradual development of asymmetrical lower limb weakness, reduced reflexes in both the knees and ankles, saddle anesthesia, difficulty voiding, a decreased anal tone, and severe back pain with radiation to the lower limb is the classic clinical picture of cauda equina syndrome (CES). CES is typically caused by traumatic injury, disk herniation, or a tumor below the level of the L2 vertebra. Given the history of prostate cancer in this patient, spinal imaging is needed to rule out vertebral or epidural metastases.

Key learning point: Cauda equina syndrome presents with asymmetric lower limb weakness, saddle anesthesia, decreased reflexes, bladder dysfunction, and reduced anal sphincter tone, often due to compression below the L2 vertebral level.
Image Description:

1 (conus medullaris syndrome): disc herniation at L1-L2 with pressure on the conus medullaris

2 (cauda equina syndrome): disc herniation at L3-L4 with pressure on the cauda equina

While disk herniation has been used to illustrate the process here, any pathology that compresses the conus medullaris or cauda equina can result in these syndromes.

D) INCORRECT:

Anterior spinal cord syndrome may lead to difficulty voiding because the descending pathways that control sphincter function are located ventrally in the spinal cord. However, it would also cause symmetrical lower limb weakness and loss of pain and temperature sensations in all areas below the level of the lesion.

E) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome in the thoracic spinal cord segments would produce symmetrical lower limb weakness, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation, which is not reported in this patient. Sensation around the buttocks, inner thighs, and genitalia, as well as anal sphincter tone are classically spared in central cord syndrome.
questions.hint: Two key factors that differentiate this diagnosis are the strong unilateral radicular pain and asymmetrical weakness.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the emergency department with a 3-week history of low back pain and a 3- to 4-day history of bilateral leg weakness and fever. This morning, he became unable to walk due to weakness, and the pain now radiates down his legs. On examination, he has lower-extremity weakness and back pain, a temperature of 39.0°C, an extensor plantar response, hyperreflexia in the lower extremities, and decreased anal sphincter tone. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Obtain a plain-film series of the spine.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although plain films are the least expensive imaging modality and are easy to obtain, they have significant limitations for detecting spinal cord compression. They can be useful for evaluating osseous structures and alignment of vertebrae, but they cannot assess the spinal cord and are no longer considered a first-line imaging tool when spinal cord compression is suspected.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms suggestive of acute spinal cord compression, including lower-extremity weakness and pain, reduced anal sphincter tone, and an upgoing plantar reflex. His fever and rapid onset of symptoms are suggestive of an acute process that should be treated as a medical emergency. Although prompt treatment is imperative to the preservation or return of function, urgent imaging is necessary to guide the appropriate diagnostic workup and therapy.

MRI is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for spinal cord compression. It is useful to assess soft tissues, ligaments, disks, and the spinal cord. It can identify the presence of an epidural mass compressing the spinal cord as well as metastatic disease within the cord, which may be missed on CT. High T2-signal abnormalities above and below the site of compression can indicate the presence of edema, suggesting an acute compression.

Key learning point: Patients who present with lower-extremity weakness, back and leg pain, and upgoing toes on plantar reflex testing should undergo MRI to rule out spinal cord compression.

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture, used to diagnose meningitis or encephalitis, is not indicated in this patient, as he does not have signs or symptoms consistent with a meningeal process.

D) INCORRECT:

Management for a patient presenting with signs of spinal cord compression may include intravenous dexamethasone to reduce edema before definitive management with surgical decompression, chemotherapy, or in some cancers, radiation therapy. Because imaging may not distinguish an infectious process (such as a spinal epidermal abscess) from a lymphoma or sarcoma, consultation with neurosurgery, oncology, and infectious disease is recommended before initiating glucocorticoids. Imaging would precede administration of glucocorticoids, however. If an infectious process is unlikely and awaiting subspecialty consultation will significantly delay management (such as may be the case in a smaller or rural hospital), intravenous glucocorticoids should be considered with the goal of preserving function.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute and subacute presentations of spinal cord compression should raise concern for a malignant etiology. Sarcoma, lymphoma, neuroblastoma, and in rare instances, leukemia have all been reported to cause spinal cord compression in children. An infectious process, such as a spinal epidural abscess, may also manifest with fever, back pain, and weakness. However, definitive imaging, such as MRI, should be performed before initiation of antibiotics. Imaging may reveal a rim-enhancing lesion, and a cerebrospinal fluid sample for culture would ideally be obtained before treatment initiation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-week history of worsening lower back pain. He reports that the pain is most intense with movement and sometimes occurs at night. Over the past 3 months, he has also noticed a weakened urinary stream. On examination, there are no spinal deformities. Palpation of the lumbar spinal process elicits localized tenderness. Muscle strength and sensation are normal bilaterally. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his back pain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar muscle strain is the most common cause of lower back pain. Muscle strain can manifest with lower back pain that is most intense with movement, reproducible on palpation, and not associated with sensory or motor dysfunction. Nocturnal pain and a weakened urinary stream, however, are not associated with lumbar strain. Moreover, lumbar muscle strain is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals with osteoporosis have an increased susceptibility to pathological vertebral compression fractures. These fractures may manifest with lower back pain and point tenderness. However, a more acute presentation would be expected in a fracture. Moreover, osteoporosis most commonly affects postmenopausal women, individuals > 70 years of age, and individuals with risk factors such as long-term steroid therapy. While vertebral compression fractures can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar disk herniation can manifest with severe lower back pain. However, disk herniation typically manifests with an acute stabbing pain that radiates to the legs and is associated with neurological deficits, such as paresthesia, loss of deep tendon reflexes, and muscle weakness. Moreover, disk herniation is usually triggered by physical exertion (e.g., bending, heavy lifting), which this patient has not reported. While a large posteromedial disk herniation can lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower back pain is a common manifestation of lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS), a condition that mostly affects individuals > 60 years of age. LSS typically causes bilateral radiating pain to the buttocks and/or legs that is exacerbated by activities involving lumbar extension (e.g., standing, walking downhill) and relieved by lumbar flexion (e.g., sitting or lying down when sleeping). Furthermore, he does not have typical symptoms of LSS, such as cramping, numbness, weakness, or tingling in the legs. While LSS can rarely lead to urinary retention symptoms secondary to cauda equina syndrome, this patient's normal sensorimotor function makes such a diagnosis unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Subacute progressive lumbar back pain and a weakened urinary stream in a patient > 50 years of age should raise suspicion for advanced-stage prostate cancer with bony metastasis. Prostate cancer is frequently associated with skeletal metastases, with the spine being the most common location. Accordingly, some patients present with lower back pain as the initial manifestation. Red flags for metastatic bone disease include a history of cancer, advanced age, unexplained weight loss, and bone pain that does not improve after one month. Besides pain, which commonly occurs at night and exacerbates with movement, patients with metastatic bone disease from prostate cancer can present with pathologic fractures, hypocalcemia (due to osteoblastic metastasis), and neurological deficits (due to spinal cord compression).

Key learning point: In older adults, persistent or progressive back pain—especially with nocturnal symptoms or urinary changes—should raise suspicion for malignancy, such as metastatic prostate cancer to the spine.
questions.hint: The most important risk factor for this patient's underlying disease is advanced age (> 50 years).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with intermittent lower back pain for 1 week. His symptoms started after lifting heavy boxes at work. He reports no fever, chills, or weight loss. He has a history of recurrent peptic ulcer disease and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there is mild paraspinal lumbar tenderness. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A spine x-ray is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are indicated as first-line agents in the treatment of acute, uncomplicated back pain for the short-term relief of symptoms. If pain relief is inadequate with NSAID monotherapy or if the patient has contraindications to NSAID therapy (e.g., peptic ulcer disease, renal dysfunction), short-term use of a nonbenzodiazepine muscle relaxant (e.g., cyclobenzaprine, tizanidine, metaxalone) can be considered as an adjunctive or alternative treatment option. Acetaminophen has limited efficacy for treating acute lower back pain but can also be considered in patients with contraindications to NSAIDs. Selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g., celecoxib) are another treatment option for patients who require gastric protection. In addition to pharmacological management, early mobilization, superficial application of heat, spinal manipulation, and massage are also recommended. Most cases of acute back pain self-resolve within 4–6 weeks.

Key learning point: For acute back pain in patients with contraindications to NSAID therapy, short-term use of a nonbenzodiazepine muscle relaxant can be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspirin is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that may be used for mild musculoskeletal pain. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease because they reduce the production of gastroprotective prostaglandins, increasing the risk of complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.

C) INCORRECT:

Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that may be used for mild musculoskeletal pain. However, NSAIDs are contraindicated in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease because they reduce the production of gastroprotective prostaglandins, increasing the risk of complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioids (e.g., oxycodone, tramadol) are not indicated as first-line therapy for patients with only mild musculoskeletal back pain. Instead, they are used in the treatment of severe or refractory back pain (e.g., tumor pain).
questions.hint: Conservative management with analgesics and physical therapy is recommended for acute, mild musculoskeletal back pain, but some medications can exacerbate preexisting comorbidities and pharmacotherapy should therefore be chosen carefully.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to your clinic with severe lower back pain for the past 2 days. The pain is constant, nonradiating, and rated as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The pain started after he helped a friend move into a new apartment. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are old track marks on both cubital fossae. His lumbar paraspinal muscles are firm and tense on palpation. There is no midline spinal tenderness. Straight leg raise to 70° on both sides does not cause pain. Sensation is intact. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar x-ray is indicated if a vertebral compression fracture is suspected. While lumbar compression fractures also present with lower back pain, they usually occur in patients at risk of pathological fracture (e.g., > 50 years old, osteoporosis, or malignancy) or after significant trauma (e.g., motor vehicle collision) and cause midline point tenderness on exam. This patient is young, has no clear risk factors for compression fracture, did not experience significant trauma, and has no midline tenderness.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the spine may be indicated in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion of a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks. This patient has none of the typical features (e.g., fever, rigors, specific tender point, neurological deficits) of an infection, and his recent history and physical examination strongly suggest acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

C) INCORRECT:

Although refraining from strenuous activity is prudent for back strain, strict bed rest is not recommended because this may actually lead to deconditioning and worse pain. Studies have shown that bed rest is associated with a lengthier recovery time compared to mild to moderate activity in patients with acute musculoskeletal lower back pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Epidural glucocorticoid injections may provide modest symptomatic relief in patients with lumbosacral radiculopathy that persists for > 6 months. This patient has no signs of radiculopathy, and he has only had symptoms for 2 days, so epidural glucocorticoids are not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Analgesia, preferably with NSAIDs, and continuation of normal activities (except strenuous exercise) is the treatment of choice for acute musculoskeletal lower back pain. Almost all cases of musculoskeletal lower back pain resolve on their own within ∼ 6 weeks. Analgesia reduces discomfort, and mild to moderate activity is associated with better outcomes than bed rest. Further testing (e.g., MRI) should be considered in patients with back pain if there is high suspicion for a serious or urgent underlying cause (e.g., spinal infection) and in individuals whose symptoms have not significantly improved after ∼ 6 weeks.

Key learning point: Acute musculoskeletal lower back pain is best managed with analgesia and continued normal activity, as most cases resolve without imaging or bed rest.
questions.hint: This patient has acute back pain without features of radiculopathy or myelopathy (e.g., shooting or shock-like pain, weakness, numbness) following a task that likely involved lifting heavy objects, which is consistent with acute lower back strain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with lower back pain for 3 days. He reports the pain is 7/10, constant, and interferes with sleep. He has a history of prostate cancer treated 2 years ago with no recent follow-up. Vital signs are normal. Neurological examination shows 4/5 strength in both legs with sustained clonus and upgoing toes bilaterally. He reports some numbness in his perineal area and states he has been straining to urinate. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Order CT scan of the spine
Obtain urgent MRI of the spine
Administer ketorolac and reassess in 4 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While CT imaging might eventually be useful for staging if metastatic disease is confirmed, the immediate emergency is potential spinal cord compression. CT is not the definitive imaging study to evaluate for cord compression and guide urgent management.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has multiple red flags, including age > 50 years, cancer history, night pain, and, most critically, signs of spinal cord compression. These findings constitute a compressive spinal emergency requiring immediate MRI for diagnosis and urgent neurosurgical consultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Pain medication alone is inappropriate when neurological deficits suggest spinal cord compression. Spinal cord compression represents a medical emergency requiring immediate imaging and surgical evaluation, not symptomatic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

While urinary symptoms are present, they are likely due to a neurological issue and not a primary urological problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is not appropriate in this patient whose neurological deficits suggest spinal cord compression.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who works in an office presents with acute lower back pain that started 3 days ago while lifting boxes during a home move. The pain is described as throbbing and localized to the lower lumbar region without radiation. He reports difficulty sleeping due to positional discomfort but denies bowel or bladder dysfunction. Physical examination shows normal vital signs, tenderness over the L4–L5 paraspinal muscles with mild spasm, and full range of motion with discomfort at extremes. Neurological examination shows 5/5 strength in all muscle groups, intact sensation, normal reflexes, and a negative straight leg raise test bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order magnetic resonance imaging of the lumbar spine
Prescribe muscle relaxants and bed rest
Initiate nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and activity modification

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging is not routinely recommended for acute nonspecific back pain without red flags or neurological deficits. Advanced imaging should be reserved for patients with persistent symptoms after 4–6 weeks of conservative management or those with concerning features.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthopedic surgery referral is not indicated for acute nonspecific back pain without neurological deficits or structural abnormalities. Surgical consultation should be reserved for patients with progressive neurological symptoms or those who do not respond to conservative management.

C) INCORRECT:

While muscle relaxants may provide short-term symptom relief, bed rest is not recommended, as it can worsen outcomes and delay recovery. Early mobilization and return to normal activities as tolerated is preferred over prolonged rest.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with typical nonspecific mechanical back pain following a precipitating event, with normal neurological examination and no red flag features. Conservative management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and activity modification is first-line treatment, as most nonspecific mechanical back pain resolves within 6 weeks without intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

X-ray imaging is not indicated for acute nonspecific back pain in patients without red flag features. This patient has no concerning features such as significant trauma, age > 50 years, neurological deficits, or constitutional symptoms that warrant imaging.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with diabetes on long-term glucocorticoids presents with 4 days of lower back pain and fever. She has mild bilateral leg weakness and reports difficulty with bowel movements. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 95; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Which diagnostic study is most appropriate?

choices.text: MRI spine with and without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture does not provide the structural imaging needed to diagnose spinal cord compression or epidural abscess. In patients with suspected epidural abscess, lumbar puncture may introduce infection.

B) INCORRECT:

CT spine without contrast is primarily used to diagnose vertebral fractures and cannot adequately evaluate for spinal infections or assess spinal cord compression.

C) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies including CBC and inflammatory markers support the diagnosis of infection, but they do not provide the structural information needed to diagnose spinal cord compression.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with red flags including long-term glucocorticoid use, fever, bilateral neurological deficits, and decreased rectal tone, suggesting spinal infection with cord compression.

E) INCORRECT:

X-ray lumbar spine has limited sensitivity for detecting spinal infections and provides inadequate information about spinal cord involvement.

questions.text: A 62-year-old construction worker presents with acute lower back pain that started 3 days ago while moving things around the house. He reports moderate pain (6/10) localized to the lumbar region without radiation. He has been taking ibuprofen with minimal relief. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination is unremarkable. He requests something stronger for pain and asks about activity restrictions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Recommend bed rest until pain subsides

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging is not routinely recommended for nonspecific back pain without red flags.

B) INCORRECT:

Opioids are not preferred for nonspecific back pain and should be avoided. NSAIDs remain the preferred analgesic option when pain management is needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Muscle relaxants are considered alternative therapy for short-term use if needed, but should be avoided in older adults..

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Early mobilization and maintaining daily activities are essential components of conservative management, as avoiding bed rest promotes faster recovery.

E) INCORRECT:

Bed rest is not recommended for nonspecific back pain because it can exacerbate symptoms and delay recovery. Patients should be encouraged to maintain daily activities and avoid prolonged inactivity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker presents with lower back pain that started 3 days ago while lifting bricks. The pain is 7/10 and constant. He has no fever, denies bowel or bladder changes, and reports no leg weakness. Neurological examination shows normal strength, sensation, and reflexes bilaterally. Straight leg raise is negative. The patient is agreeable to discharge, but asks if he can be prescribed something for the pain. What is the most appropriate medication to prescribe?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids should be avoided as first-line therapy for nonspecific back pain management due to risk of dependence and limited evidence of benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids are not recommended for the treatment of nonspecific back pain.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – NSAIDs are the preferred first-line analgesic for nonspecific back pain in patients without contraindications.

D) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is an adjuvant analgesic that should not be used as first-line therapy as it lacks evidence for routine use in nonspecific back pain and is associated with potential adverse effects.

E) INCORRECT:

Antidepressants may be considered for use in chronic back pain but are not appropriate for this patient with acute nonnspecific back pain.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with acute onset of low back pain radiating to both legs, progressive bilateral leg weakness, and urinary incontinence developing over 8 hours. Physical examination shows symmetrical bilateral weakness that is greater distally than proximally in the lower extremities, hyperreflexia, and bilateral perianal numbness. Pain and temperature sensation are diminished in the lower extremities and remain intact in the upper extremities. What is the most likely anatomical location of the lesion?

choices.text: Posterior spinal cord at L3–L4 level
Central spinal cord at L1-L2 level
Anterior spinal cord at L1-L2 level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterior cord syndrome causes bilateral loss of proprioception and sense of vibration, but motor function is preserved. Motor weakness and early bladder dysfunction are not consistent with isolated posterior column involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

Central cord syndrome typically affects the upper extremities more than lower extremities and does not cause the specific pattern of bilateral perianal numbness and early bladder incontinence characteristic of sacral segment involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Cauda equina syndrome typically manifests with a gradual onset, asymmetrical presentation, and areflexic flaccid paresis. Late-onset urinary retention rather than early incontinence and saddle anesthesia pattern are more characteristic than the symmetrical bilateral findings seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conus medullaris syndrome affects the sacral and coccygeal spinal segments at vertebral levels T12–L2. The sudden onset, symmetrical bilateral presentation, hyperreflexic distal paresis, early bladder incontinence, and characteristic perianal numbness with sensory dissociation are classic features of conus medullaris syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior cord syndrome causes bilateral motor paralysis and loss of pain and temperature sensation, but it does not specifically cause the symmetrical bilateral perianal numbness and hyperreflexia pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, early bladder incontinence is not a characteristic of anterior cord syndrome.

questions.text: A 42-year-old office manager presents with a 3-week history of non-radiating low back pain that began after moving furniture. He reports the pain is "unbearable" and is worried it might be something serious, preventing him from engaging in his usual exercise routine. His physical exam is notable only for mild paraspinal tenderness, with no neurologic deficits. He expresses significant distress about the possibility of long-term disability. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for the transition to chronic back pain?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's report of "unbearable" pain, worry about a serious cause, and avoidance of exercise despite a benign physical exam are classic manifestations of fear-avoidance beliefs. This psychosocial model suggests that negative cognitive and emotional responses to pain, such as catastrophizing (worrying that the pain is worse than it is), lead to fear of movement and subsequent activity avoidance. This avoidance results in physical deconditioning, disability, and a heightened pain experience, creating a vicious cycle. These psychosocial factors, often termed "yellow flags," are among the strongest predictors for the transition from acute to chronic low back pain and disability, more so than the physical findings themselves.

B) INCORRECT:

While pain duration defines the stage of back pain (acute is less than four weeks), the three-week duration itself is not the most significant risk factor for chronicity. The vast majority of acute low back pain episodes resolve spontaneously within four to six weeks. Therefore, a three-week duration falls within the expected timeframe for an uncomplicated acute episode.

C) INCORRECT:

Mild paraspinal muscle tenderness is a common and expected physical finding in acute mechanical low back pain, reflecting localized muscle strain or spasm. The presence of this mild finding is consistent with the acute injury but does not, in itself, predict the likelihood of the pain becoming chronic. In fact, its mild nature contrasts with the patient's high level of distress.

D) INCORRECT:

The absence of neurologic deficits, such as weakness, sensory loss, or reflex changes, is a reassuring finding. It indicates a lack of significant nerve root compression or spinal cord involvement. This is actually a favorable prognostic indicator suggesting a lower likelihood of serious underlying pathology, rather than a risk factor for developing chronic pain.
questions.hint: Chronic back pain is back pain that persists for more than 12 weeks, even after the initial injury or underlying cause has been treated or has healed.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive, dull low back pain. The pain is constant but is most severe at night, often waking him from sleep. He reports no relief with rest or over-the-counter analgesics. He has also experienced unintentional 6.5-kg (15-lb) weight loss and generalized fatigue during this period. His medical history is notable for prostate cancer, treated with radical prostatectomy 7 years ago. On examination, there is focal tenderness to palpation over the L4 vertebra. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally, and neurologic examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar spinal stenosis is a common cause of back pain in this age group. However, it characteristically presents with neurogenic claudication, which is pain, numbness, or weakness in the legs that is exacerbated by walking or standing (spinal extension) and relieved by sitting or leaning forward (spinal flexion). This patient's pain is constant and worse at night, which is not typical for spinal stenosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation includes multiple red flags for a malignant cause of back pain. Key features include age over 50, a history of cancer (prostate cancer, which commonly metastasizes to bone), nocturnal pain that awakens the patient from sleep, and pain that is constant and not relieved by rest. The presence of constitutional symptoms like unintentional weight loss and fatigue further supports a systemic neoplastic process. On examination, the focal vertebral tenderness points to a specific bony lesion rather than a diffuse musculoskeletal issue. These findings are typical of metastatic disease, where tumor infiltration of the vertebra causes pain through periosteal stretching, microfractures, and irritation of adjacent nerve roots.

C) INCORRECT:

Degenerative disc disease is a common cause of chronic low back pain in older adults. However, the pain is typically mechanical in nature, meaning it is worsened by activity and improves with rest. This patient's pain is constant, worse at night, and not relieved by rest. Furthermore, degenerative disc disease does not explain this patient's significant unintentional weight loss.

D) INCORRECT:

An osteoporotic compression fracture typically presents with acute, severe pain and focal vertebral tenderness, often after minimal trauma. While it can cause chronic pain, the pain usually improves over weeks. This patient's 3-month history of progressive pain, nocturnal worsening, and significant weight loss are not characteristic of a benign osteoporotic fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

Vertebral osteomyelitis can cause constant, severe back pain, focal vertebral tenderness, and may be worse at night. However, it is typically associated with risk factors such as recent infection, intravenous drug use, immunosuppression, or a recent spinal procedure, none of which are mentioned here. While constitutional symptoms can occur, fever is more common than the significant weight loss described.
questions.hint: Consider the significance of persistent back pain that is worse at night, is not relieved by rest, and is accompanied by constitutional symptoms in a patient with a history of cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of persistent low back pain. The pain is a dull ache in the lumbosacral region, occasionally radiating to his left buttock but not down the leg. It is exacerbated by prolonged standing and lifting at his construction job and improves with rest. He has tried over-the-counter ibuprofen with minimal benefit. He denies fever, weight loss, or new urinary or bowel symptoms. His physical examination reveals paraspinal muscle tenderness and limited lumbar flexion. A straight leg raise test is negative, and neurologic examination of the lower extremities is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a short course of oxycodone
Obtain an MRI of the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioids may be considered for severe pain, but they are not a first-line therapy for chronic low back pain due to the high risk of dependence, tolerance, and adverse effects, with limited evidence for long-term functional improvement. Guidelines recommend exhausting non-opioid pharmacologic therapies first. This patient's presentation does not warrant initiating opioid therapy as the next step.

B) INCORRECT:

A surgical referral is plausible for persistent pain, but it is premature in this case. Surgical consultation is indicated for patients with severe or progressive neurologic deficits, spinal instability, or pain refractory to standard conservative therapies.

C) INCORRECT:

While an MRI provides detailed images of the spine, routine imaging is not indicated for chronic low back pain in the absence of red flags (e.g., fever, weight loss, new neurologic deficits, history of cancer) or progressive symptoms. Incidental findings are common in asymptomatic individuals and can lead to unnecessary anxiety and interventions. Imaging should be reserved for when results would change management, such as before a planned epidural injection or surgery.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has chronic (>12 weeks), non-specific mechanical low back pain without neurologic deficits or red flag symptoms. Current guidelines strongly recommend non-pharmacologic therapies as the initial treatment. Physical therapy is a cornerstone of this approach, focusing on supervised exercise, core strengthening, improving flexibility, and patient education on proper body mechanics. This directly addresses the likely musculoskeletal and biomechanical causes of his pain, which is exacerbated by his occupation. Other first-line options include acupuncture, spinal manipulation, and mindfulness-based stress reduction. Pharmacologic treatment is typically reserved for patients who do not respond to non-pharmacologic interventions.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclobenzaprine is a skeletal muscle relaxant. While it can be useful for acute musculoskeletal back pain (present for <4 weeks), its efficacy for chronic low back pain is not well-established. It is generally recommended for short-term use due to side effects like sedation and dizziness.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation is suggestive of chronic low back pain with no red flag features.

questions.text: A 35-year-old construction worker comes to the office because of a 2-day history of severe lower back pain. The pain began acutely after he lifted a heavy box at work. The pain is localized to the lumbar region, does not radiate, and is described as a deep ache that worsens with movement. He has no fever, bowel or bladder dysfunction, or lower extremity weakness. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lumbar paraspinal muscles and limited flexion due to pain. Neurologic examination, including straight leg raise, is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Instruct the patient to maintain strict bed rest for 48 hours
Advise to remain active as tolerated and apply superficial heat

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Skeletal muscle relaxants like cyclobenzaprine can be considered for acute low back pain, particularly with significant muscle spasm. However, they are typically recommended as a second-line option if initial non-pharmacologic therapies are insufficient. Given their potential for sedation and other side effects, initiating treatment with non-pharmacologic measures is preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen are an appropriate pharmacologic option for acute low back pain. However, current guidelines recommend initiating treatment with non-pharmacologic therapies first. If the patient does not improve with activity modification and heat, then NSAIDs would be a reasonable next step.

C) INCORRECT:

While resting seems intuitive for an injury, strict bed rest is an outdated recommendation that has been shown to be ineffective and potentially harmful for acute low back pain. It can lead to muscle deconditioning, joint stiffness, and a slower recovery. Current guidelines strongly advocate for continuing ordinary activities as tolerated.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging is plausible given the acute pain, but it is not indicated for acute low back pain without red flag signs or symptoms. This patient has no history of significant trauma, cancer, infection, or neurologic deficits. Routine imaging in such cases does not improve outcomes and exposes the patient to unnecessary radiation.

E) CORRECT:

First-line management for acute low back pain prioritizes non-pharmacologic therapies. Patients should be counseled to remain active as tolerated, as bed rest can delay recovery and lead to deconditioning. Superficial heat is an effective modality for reducing pain and muscle spasm. This approach, focusing on education and self-care, has been shown to improve outcomes and is recommended by major clinical guidelines as the initial step before considering pharmacologic interventions.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is classic for acute mechanical low back pain, likely a lumbar strain, without any red flag symptoms like neurologic deficits or bowel/bladder dysfunction

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 2-day history of severe lower back pain. The pain began suddenly while he was lifting a heavy box. He describes the pain as a sharp, aching sensation localized to the lumbar region that worsens with movement. He denies any radiation of pain down his legs, weakness, or changes in bowel or bladder function. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation over the lumbar paraspinal muscles and limited lumbar flexion. A straight leg raise test is negative bilaterally, and lower extremity strength and sensation are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe NSAIDs and continuation of usual activities
Advise strict bed rest for 48 hours
Prescribe a short course of an opioid analgesic

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has acute, uncomplicated mechanical low back pain, likely a lumbar strain. The cornerstone of initial management is conservative treatment. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are the first-line pharmacologic treatment to reduce pain and inflammation. Evidence shows that continuing usual activities as tolerated leads to faster recovery and less disability compared to prescribed bed rest. This approach addresses symptoms while promoting functional recovery. Most patients with acute mechanical back pain improve significantly within a few weeks with this management.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is an effective treatment for low back pain, but it is generally not the first-line intervention for an acute, uncomplicated episode. A referral for physical therapy is more appropriate if the pain does not improve within 2–4 weeks or if it becomes recurrent or chronic.

C) INCORRECT:

While resting an injury seems intuitive, strict bed rest is no longer recommended for acute mechanical low back pain. Studies have shown that bed rest can lead to muscle deconditioning, prolonged recovery time, and an increased risk of chronic pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging is plausible due to the acute onset of pain after lifting. However, lumbar spine imaging is not indicated in the initial evaluation of acute low back pain in the absence of red flag signs or symptoms. This patient is young and has no neurologic deficits, history of cancer, fever, or significant trauma that would warrant imaging to rule out fracture, malignancy, or infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Opioids may seem appropriate for a patient reporting severe pain. However, they are not first-line therapy for acute, uncomplicated low back pain due to their significant side effect profile and potential for misuse and dependence. Opioids should be considered only for severe, refractory pain and for the shortest possible duration.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is classic for acute mechanical low back pain. Note the absence of red flag symptoms such as radiculopathy, weakness, or bowel or bladder dysfunction, which guides the initial management strategy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe, worsening low back pain that began after lifting a heavy box. The pain radiates down both legs to the feet. He also reports new numbness in his groin and buttocks, which he noticed when wiping after a bowel movement. He has had increasing difficulty initiating a urinary stream over the past few hours. On examination, he has bilateral weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion. Sensation is diminished over the perineum and posterior thighs. Ankle reflexes are absent bilaterally, and a rectal examination shows decreased sphincter tone. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transverse myelitis is an inflammatory process of the spinal cord that can cause weakness, sensory changes, and autonomic dysfunction. However, it is an upper motor neuron disorder, which would typically lead to hyperreflexia and spasticity after the initial period of spinal shock. This patient's absent reflexes are a clear lower motor neuron sign. Additionally, transverse myelitis is not precipitated by a mechanical event such as heavy lifting.

B) INCORRECT:

Conus medullaris syndrome can also manifest with back pain and bowel and bladder dysfunction. However, it results from injury to the terminal spinal cord (L1–L2 level) and typically manifests with a mixture of upper and lower motor neuron signs. The pain is often less severe and radicular compared to this patient's condition, and the neurologic deficits are more likely to be symmetric at onset. This patient's purely lower motor neuron signs (areflexia) and severe radicular pain make this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a herniated disc is the likely underlying cause, this diagnosis is incomplete. A typical herniated nucleus pulposus with radiculopathy involves compression of a single nerve root, causing unilateral symptoms in a specific dermatomal and myotomal distribution. This patient's presentation with bilateral leg weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel and bladder dysfunction indicates compression of multiple nerve roots, which constitutes a more severe syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

A spinal epidural abscess can cause progressive neurologic deficits and back pain. However, patients typically present with signs of infection, most notably fever, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, the onset is usually subacute, and risk factors such as intravenous drug use, a recent spinal procedure, or diabetes are often present. The acute onset immediately following a mechanical trigger makes an infectious cause unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for cauda equina syndrome, a neurosurgical emergency caused by compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots. Key features include severe low back pain, bilateral sciatica, saddle anesthesia (numbness in the S3–S5 dermatomes), and autonomic dysfunction, such as the urinary retention and decreased rectal tone seen in this patient. The physical examination findings of bilateral lower extremity weakness and absent ankle reflexes are characteristic of a lower motor neuron injury affecting multiple nerve roots. The most common cause is a large, central lumbar disc herniation, often precipitated by an event such as heavy lifting. Urgent MRI and surgical decompression are required to prevent permanent deficits.
questions.hint: Bilateral sciatica, saddle anesthesia, and new-onset urinary retention suggest a neurosurgical emergency involving multiple lumbosacral nerve roots.
